visual_elements.description: A table defining 'Grade' based on 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.'. It contains three rows of definitions for different scenarios.

Figure 45: Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%. It shows two houses on a sloped terrain. Dashed lines indicate the existing grade (before fill) and the finished grade. Arrows indicate 'Height' measurements from the grade to the roof peak. Two horizontal lines are labeled '30' above existing grade' and '30' above finished'. A text box explains that the structure must comply with the lower of the two limits.

Figure 44: Existing vs. Finished grade. This diagram illustrates a single house with its foundation. It shows the 'Existing grade (before fill)' and 'Finished grade (after fill)'. An arrow indicates 'Height: measured to top of roof material of the highest peak'. A callout points to the 'Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure'.
Figure 46: Comparison of different grades. A line graph with a grid, showing four diagonal lines representing different slopes: 1:10 (10%), 3:10 (33%), 5:10 (50%), and 10:10 (100%).

technical_specifications.parameter: Natural slope for Existing Grade definition
